page.title: 05Farming 2: Sheep Farming
page.content: Swaledale sheep are the main breed, kept pure and heafed on the commons and fells. There are two Herdwick flocks. Each farm has an ear and smit mark; there is a "Shepherds' Guide" to help identify stray sheep. Hoggs are wintered on lowland farms. "Inside" ewes are mated in November with Blue-faced Leicester rams to produce cross lambs called Mules in March/ April. These are sold at 5 months fat or for breeding. Farmers still help each other on clipping days when the sheep are sheared by machine. October is a busy month for selling lambs and for buying replacement ewes and rams. All farms have a working sheep dog, and the younger farmers gather sheep from the fell by motor-cycle. Sheep have, by law to be dipped twice a year to prevent the spread of sheep scab.
